The volunteers departed, the defense committee assembled and while naturally enough all felt that prompt measures must be taken, there was some diversity of opinion regarding what should be done. It was finally decided that in case of attack Mr. Col. Spratt command the volunteers at Duck Lake. As Mr. McKay agreed to assist, Mr. Col. Spratt command the volunteers at Duck Lake where Mr. McKay was appointed assistant to Mr. Col. Spratt. They met near the fort where they were joined by a number of men from Fort Erie. Since Mr. McKay was questioned about the existence of two men named McKay living near the fort, Mr. McKay replied that he had seen two men named McKay living near the fort.

In the meantime, the volunteers assembled at Duck Lake and marched westward toward Fort Erie. On the way, they met another group of volunteers who had heard about the situation at Fort Erie. Mr. McKay rejoined them and together they marched toward Fort Erie.

At Fort Erie, they were met by Mr. Col. Spratt who informed them of the situation inside the fort. Mr. McKay then addressed the volunteers and requested their assistance in repelling any attack. The volunteers readily agreed and proceeded to Fort Erie where they joined forces with those already present at the fort.

On the following day, Mr. McKay led a group of volunteers on a reconnaissance mission to investigate the movements of the enemy. During the mission, they encountered a party of Indians who were hostile to the volunteers. Despite the threat, Mr. McKay managed to negotiate a truce with the Indians and gained valuable information about the enemy's plans.

Back at Fort Erie, the volunteers were put to work strengthening the fortifications and preparing for any possible attack. Mr. McKay continued to lead the volunteers and instilled confidence in their abilities to defend the fort.

In conclusion, Mr. McKay demonstrated exceptional leadership skills and courage throughout the events described. His dedication to the cause and his determination to protect the fortification made him an inspiring figure for the volunteers under his command.
